title: What kind of relationship did Edward VIII and George VI have? Did they love one another as brothers? - Quora
tags: King George VI of the United Kingdom

response.answer_text: They were quite close prior to Edward’s relationship with Wallis Simpson, bearing in mind just how insensitive and sarcastic Edward could be at times. It’s also important to remember that Prince Albert was the more settled brother. He’d married in 1923 and became a father in 1926. During all that time, Edward was making extensive world tours, and generally being the star of the Royal Family. It’s also a fact that Edward was undoubtedly closer to his youngest surviving brother, Prince George, who was closer in personality to Edward than Albert was. Nevertheless there are plenty of examples Edward and Bertie spending time together, and essentially having fun together. Bertie and Elizabeth were even cordial with some of Edward’s mistresses. There’s a photo in Sarah Bradford’s book The Reluctant King of a pool party at Edward’s residence Fort Belvedere which included Edward’s mistress at the time, Lady Furness. The brothers golfed together - Bertie was a far better golfer than his brother- and there’s the famous story of Edward and Bertie trying to discover how unbreakable some “unbreakable” records from America really were. Things changed a lot when Mrs. Simpson was added into the mix. Albert was a religious man and a stickler for “form” and propriety. Of the two brothers he was also closest to their father, and a lot of the animosity that developed sprang from these factors. Edward’s other mistresses hadn’t tried to insert themselves into all aspects of Edward’s life; they had been content to be part of his private life. But Mrs. Simpson was always there and intruded into some public events. Edward lied about his relationship to his father, managed to get the Simpson’s presented to the King and Queen, was invited to Edward’s private area at his first (and only) Trooping of the Colours as King. The relationship between the brothers grew strained as events moved towards their climax and the abdication. It was after the abdication that the relationship was irreparably destroyed. Some of the issues were petty, like the matter of how the Duchess of Windsor would be styled. Others were more serious, specifically the matter of money. The Duke of Windsor had a habit of “crying poor” even though he had managed to retain funds from the Duchy of Cornwall, and had substantial resources of his own. Then there was the way that he tried to behave as though he were still King, making a radio speech to the United States and being greeted almost as a head of state in Germany by the Nazis. Edward’s behaviour once the war started, including his trip to Spain around the time of the Fall of a France. His behaviour as Governor of the Bahamas, where he engaged in illegal currency trading, was another embarrassment. It’s safe to say that by the time of George VI’s death, the relationship between Edward and the man he disdainfully called “Mr Temple”, which had once been close was irrevocably shattered.
